title: 108_hr1310
content: The "Reforestation Tax Act of 2003" may be cited as the official title. It includes a partial inflation adjustment for timber in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Reforestation Tax Act of 2003" allows taxpayers with qualified timber gain to deduct a percentage of the gain from gross income. Qualified timber gain refers to long-term capital gain from timber sales. The qualified percentage is determined by multiplying 3 percent by the number of years the taxpayer held the timber. Estates and trusts have specific rules for computing this deduction. The tax code allows income beneficiaries of trusts to include gain from the sale of capital assets in their gross income. Additionally, there are provisions for qualified timber gain with specific rules for deductions. The tax code includes provisions for qualified timber gain, with specific rules for deductions and adjustments to adjusted gross income. Amendments are made to sections 62 and 172(d)(2) of the Code to address these deductions. Amendments are made to various sections of the tax code to include deductions under section 1203 for qualified timber gain. Adjustments are specified for deductions allowable under sections 1202 and 1203 to estates or trusts. Amendments to the tax code include adjustments for deductions under sections 1202 and 1203 for qualified timber gain in estates or trusts. Amendments to the tax code include adjustments for deductions under sections 1202 and 1203 for qualified timber gain in estates or trusts. Additionally, a clerical amendment was made to the table of sections for part I of subchapter P of chapter 1 of the Code. SEC. 199. Reforestation expenditures allow for a 100 percent deduction to replace amortization, effective for sales or exchanges after December 31, 2002. In the case of qualified timber property, a deduction is allowed for reforestation expenditures paid or incurred by the taxpayer. Qualified timber property refers to land in the US used for growing trees for commercial purposes. Reforestation expenditures are direct costs for tree planting and care. Reforestation expenditures are direct costs incurred for planting or seeding, including site preparation, seeds or seedlings, labor, and equipment depreciation. Expenditures reimbursed under governmental cost-sharing programs are not included unless the reimbursement amounts have been included in the taxpayer's gross income. Amendments are made to the tax code regarding the amortization of reforestation expenditures, with a termination clause for any expenses incurred after a certain date. The tax code is amended to include reforestation expenditures, with the changes applying to expenses incurred after the enactment of the Act.
